I have a plot generated by the following code:

```python
plt.plot(sim_1['t'],sim_1['V'],'k')
plt.ylabel('V')
plt.xlabel('t')
plt.show()
```

The resulting plot looks like this:

![Plot](https://i.stack.imgur.com/jU1uJ.png)

I want to hide the numbers on the axes. I tried using `plt.axis('off')`, but it also hides the labels `V` and `t`, as seen in the resulting image below:

![Plot with no axis](https://i.stack.imgur.com/gur0P.png)

How can I hide only the axis numbers while keeping the labels?

To hide the numbers on the axes while keeping the axis labels, you can use the `set_tick_params` method to set the visibility of the ticks to `False`. Here's how you can modify your code to achieve this:

```python
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Assuming sim_1 is already defined and contains 't' and 'V'
plt.plot(sim_1['t'], sim_1['V'], 'k')
plt.ylabel('V')
plt.xlabel('t')

# Hide the tick labels on both axes
plt.gca().tick_params(axis='both', which='both', labelbottom=False, labelleft=False)

plt.show()
```

This code will keep the axis labels `V` and `t` while hiding the numbers on both the x-axis and y-axis. The `tick_params` method is used to control the appearance of ticks, and setting `labelbottom` and `labelleft` to `False` hides the labels on the x-axis and y-axis, respectively.
